ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned SO MUCH about the law, much of which has distressed and unsettled me. Police consult psychics and use dowsing rods...
A knowledge of some of the main frameworks surrounding some crucial constitutional amendments (4th 5th 14th etc), and especially a knowledge of how they might relate to policy issues generally

KG's class brought to light a whole host of ethical questions regarding the law that I had never considered before. This class taught me to be a better thinker and even a better person by considering not just what the law says about a certain topic, but also considering what it should have said. This is one of the few classes I've had where I have been able to interrogate my personal values, especially about the justice system, and openly explore alternative ways of addressing the many problems with the carceral system.

Even as a PLSC major and someone with experience in criminal law, I learned SO much from this class! Our readings and discussions taught me a great deal about constitutional amendments and the jurisprudence surrounding them, and how they tangibly impact individuals' lives. I also learned to critically think about case law in a way I hadn't before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- Each class is themed, which provides structure
- Rousing class debates
- Wide variety of class content (videos, articles, case studies)

Weaknesses:
- Too much reading

I honestly cannot think of a way this class could have been improved -- the syllabus was well structured and our readings were fascinating, we were exposed to many different points of view on each issue, and no matter what we always were encouraged to share our personal beliefs and opinions on our topics. The seminar discussion was super engaging and genuinely fun while also covering serious and important topics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Of course!!!!

Especially if you are living in America, you should understand how weird and strange and horrifying the American legal system can be.

YES! Super interesting, and not very stressful. Cool way for more policy oriented people to dip their toe into some more theoretical/legal issues. And a good way for more theoretical people to get into some actual policy
Yes if you're interested in the criminal justice system.

Yes, absolutely. My favorite courses at Yale are ones where the instructor is solely dedicated to helping students learn and making the class an enjoyable experience. KG's class is the epitome of that. The material was highly interesting, the conversations and debates were dynamic, and the class was the highlight of my week instead of being a stress.
YES! I would recommend anything taught by Professor Goodrow, but especially this course for people interested in criminal law.
